children.text: This is Lever Weekly, a recap of our work from the past week. If you only read one email from us all week, this should be it.

Below you will find a breakdown of our reporting, podcasts, videos, and live events — a feature now open to all subscribers. Following that, we are providing paid subscribers with an original column, written by a member of

In this week’s column, exclusively for paid subscribers, David Sirota explores why billionaire Jeff Bezos’ visit to his
newsroom exemplifies how the discourse is influenced and controlled in today’s news ecosystem.

Honest reporters can still produce valuable journalism inside this dystopia (and we try to
). But they are the bug, not the feature of the corporate media system — the lonely few exploiting rare glitches in the matrix.

is to build an entirely different model from scratch — a reader-supported independent news outlet whose reporting holds the powerful accountable, whether in corporate media, in executive boardrooms, or in the halls of government. In the two-plus years since our launch, we’ve achieved proof of concept — we’ve broken open
in both parties, which has intensified pressure on public officials to act in the public’s interest.
That has won us no fans among billionaires, CEOs, elite media pundits, and both parties’ sycophants who want their politicians defended from — rather than subjected to — accountability.

For a reader-supported outlet, this catch-22 — impactful accountability reporting engendering mass backlash — remains one of the major obstacles to expanding from successful concept to larger scale. When we are mercilessly attacked for holding politicians accountable, or our content is effectively shadowbanned because it doesn’t toe a corporate or partisan line, it can drive away some reader support, making it more difficult for us to expand our reporting.
